line=39 tag=L:           b. Wo wang-le ni.
line=40 tag=B:
line=41 tag=M:  1
line=42 tag=M:    I would like to thank professors Ted Fernald and Shizhe Huang for their help at all stages of writing this thesis.
line=43 tag=M:  Thanks also go to Pen-Pen Chen, who provided her native speaker's intuition for the Mandarin data, and to the
line=44 tag=M:  Bryn Mawr College dean's office for reimbursing Pen-Pen for the time she spent working with me.
line=45 tag=M:  2
line=46 tag=M:    Where semantically predicative means [having] the capacity to constrain the number meaning and overt
line=47 tag=M:  expression of the arguments in the clause"(Mohanan (1997), Bender 455).
line=48 tag=B:
line=49 tag=B:
line=50 tag=M:                                                            1
line=51 tag=B:
line=52 tag=G:            `I forget-ASP you'
line=53 tag=T:            "I forgot you.'

doc_id=2393 igt_id=igt2393-1 295 303 L+DB M+DB G+DB M+DB L+DB M+DB G+DB M+DB T+DB
language: Mandarin Chinese (cmn)
line=295 tag=L+DB:                                                                 (16) wo3 zou2 tian1 xie3 le5 yi1 feng1 xin4 ,
line=296 tag=M+DB:  where the first verb denotes the activity, and the second
line=297 tag=G+DB:                                                                      I      yesterday write L E one C L            letter
line=298 tag=M+DB:  verb denotes the result. For verbs of perception, two dif-
line=299 tag=L+DB:                                                                      ke3 shi4 mei2        xie3 wan2
line=300 tag=M+DB:  ferent result morphemes are typically used: jian4 , best
line=301 tag=G+DB:                                                                      but       not-have write finish
line=302 tag=M+DB:  glossed as `perceive', and dao4 , literally `arrive'.
line=303 tag=T+DB:                                                                      `I wrote a letter yesterday, but I didn't finish it.'

doc_id=2393 igt_id=igt2393-2 311 316 L+DB G+DB L+DB G+DB M+DB T+DB
language: Mandarin Chinese (cmn)
line=311 tag=L+DB:  (11) ta1 kan4 le5 ban4 tian1 , ke3 shi4 mei2                      I have thus far demonstrated that the Mandarin
line=312 tag=G+DB:       he look L E half day          but       not-have          equivalent of many English verbs cannot be expressed
line=313 tag=L+DB:       kan4 jian4                                                monomorphemically, but rather must involve a verbal
line=314 tag=G+DB:       look perceive                                             compound. In order to defend my claims, however, the
line=315 tag=M+DB:                                                                 following (apparent) counterexamples must be explained:
line=316 tag=T+DB:       `He looked for a long time, but couldn't see it.'

doc_id=2393 igt_id=igt2393-3 317 321 L+DB M+DB G+DB M+DB T+DB
language: Mandarin Chinese (cmn)
line=317 tag=L+DB:                                                                 (17)    a. shu4       dao3 le5
line=318 tag=M+DB:     In contrast, using a resultative verb compound in the
line=319 tag=G+DB:                                                                            tree       fall L E
line=320 tag=M+DB:  first clause triggers a contradiction:
line=321 tag=T+DB:                                                                            `The     tree fell.'

doc_id=2393 igt_id=igt2393-5 330 335 L+DB G+DB L+DB G+DB T+DB T+DB
language: Mandarin Chinese (cmn)
line=330 tag=L+DB:      It appears that dao3 and sui4 are monomorphemic             (21)   a. wo3 kan4 jian4            shu4 dao3 zhai4
line=331 tag=G+DB:  verbs that express change of state. In order for my claims                I      see perceive tree fall at
line=332 tag=L+DB:  to be correct, I would have to demonstrate that such verbs                lu4 bian1
line=333 tag=G+DB:  are actually derived from more basic forms. Indeed, this                  road side
line=334 tag=T+DB:  is the case: the examples above are derived from underly-                 `I see the fallen tree at the side of the road.'
line=335 tag=T+DB:  ing stative predicates--the particle le signals inchoativity.             (tree may have fallen a long time ago)

line=422 tag=G+DB:             Zhangsan      fall L E tree                           pounds in Chinese is a fully productive process--the only
line=423 tag=M+DB:                                                                   constraint on verb combinations appears to stem from
line=424 tag=T+DB:             intended: `Zhangsan fell the tree.'

doc_id=3411 igt_id=igt3411-32 640 658 L+LN G B B M M M M M M M M M M M B M B T
language: Mandarin (cmn)
line=640 tag=L+LN:          (22)    qi caiwu bei yin nuren xi duoqu zhi. (Shengjing)
line=641 tag=G:                  his wealth BEI whorely woman all grabbed it
line=642 tag=B:
line=643 tag=B:
line=644 tag=M:  9 In this case, because of itslight functional load, bei comes close to having the status of an
line=645 tag=M:  auxiliary (or light verb) and theNOP having the status of the main predicate. One could go one
line=646 tag=M:  stepfurther, following Chomsky (1981) and Stowell (1981) in their treatments oftough
line=647 tag=M:  constructions, and assume that re-analysis wipes out the NOP structure andturns the variable into
line=648 tag=M:  an NP-trace in the end. For indepedent reasonshaving to do with Case theory, we shall assume
line=649 tag=M:  that this is in factpossible in some constructions though perhaps not for others. The latter point is
line=650 tag=M:  supported by the fact, as we shallsee shortly below, there are cases where the NOP movement
line=651 tag=M:  allows for theuse of resumptive pronouns. In such cases the reanalysis would result intreating a
line=652 tag=M:  resumptive pronoun as an NP-trace. This seems implausible, since NP trace isA-bound in its
line=653 tag=M:  minimal clause, and a resumptive pronoun, qua pronoun, mustbe A-free in its governing category,
line=654 tag=M:  as is well known.
line=655 tag=B:
line=656 tag=M:                                                                                                    14
line=657 tag=B:
line=658 tag=T:                 His wealth were all snapped [it] by the whorely woman.

line=662 tag=T:                 The fairiestn were seen [them] by the pool-owners.

line=1654 tag=M:  away on me.

line=2072 tag=M:
line=2073 tag=M:  38Some speakers can accept sentences like (94b), with an idiom chunkappearing in the subject
line=2074 tag=M:  position. Washio (1990, p. 258) gives the (i) asbeing fully grammatical"
line=2075 tag=M:
line=2076 tag=M:          (i)    Nowadays, advantage gets taken of little girls by adult men,
line=2077 tag=M:
line=2078 tag=M:  I assume that for these speakers the verb get has beenfurther weakened (ergativized,
line=2079 tag=M:  grammaticalized) so that in addition to themeaning `to experience', it can also have the
line=2080 tag=M:  meaningapproximating `to become, turn out'. In this latter meaning its subject isnon-thematic and
line=2081 tag=M:  can host NP-movement.The derivation would be as depictedin (90) for the be-passive:
line=2082 tag=M:  [Advantagei got [t'i [taken ti of John]], with t' being a trace ratherthan Pro.

doc_id=3506 igt_id=igt3506-6 183 194 L+EX B M M M M M B M B G T
language: Mandarin (cmn)
line=183 tag=L+EX:                 d.    *Zhangsan bei Lisi lai-le.     (no object at all)
line=184 tag=B:
line=185 tag=M:  1 The status of (5a-b) in relation to the analysis of passives was discussed in Huang (1982) and
line=186 tag=M:  Li (1990). As will be seen below, sentences of the sort represented by (5c-d) may be
line=187 tag=M:  acceptable in some languages, each with a strong sense of `adversity', e.g., Zhangsan was
line=188 tag=M:  adversely affected by Lisi hitting Wangwu or by Lisi's arrival. Some speakers of Mandarin
line=189 tag=M:  find (5c-d) marginally acceptable under the adversative reading.
line=190 tag=B:

line=192 tag=B:
line=193 tag=G:                          Zhangsan BEI Lisi come-PERF
line=194 tag=T:                          `*Zhangsan was arrived by Lisi.'

doc_id=3506 igt_id=igt3506-43 773 787 L G B M M M M M M M M B M B T
language: Mandarin (cmn)
line=773 tag=L:         (33)    xiaotou suo meiyou touzou __ de naxie shu zai zhuozi-shang
line=774 tag=G:                 thief   suo not-have steal __ DE those book at table-top
line=775 tag=B:
line=776 tag=M:  11 Hide Hoshi (personal communication) correctly points out that this argument goes through
line=777 tag=M:  only if Chinese relative clauses may be non-finite. The reason is that, as shown in (27), tough
line=778 tag=M:  movement cannot extract an element out of a finite clause, and if all relative clauses must be
line=779 tag=M:  finite in Chinese, (30) could be ruled out independently, thus providing no evidence for CNPC.
line=780 tag=M:  The question of what counts as `finite' in Chinese is an open-ended question, but given the
line=781 tag=M:  existence of infinitival relatives in English (e.g. a book to read), the burden of proof lies with
line=782 tag=M:  the supposition that Chinese relatives must always be finite. I hence take (30) as exhibiting
line=783 tag=M:  an island effect.
line=784 tag=B:
line=785 tag=M:                                                                                                    17
line=786 tag=B:
line=787 tag=T:                 The books that the thieves have not stolen are on the table.

doc_id=3506 igt_id=igt3506-44 810 812 L G T
language: Mandarin (cmn)

line=812 tag=T:                 Zhangsan was hit once by Lisi.

doc_id=3506 igt_id=igt3506-97 1377 1418 L+AC G B M B M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M B B T
language: Mandarin (cmn)
line=1377 tag=L+AC:          (iii) shi    ke      sha, bu ke          ru.       (Mingshi,181)
line=1378 tag=G:                scholar can-be killed, not can-be insulted
line=1379 tag=B:
line=1380 tag=M:                                                                                                     29
line=1381 tag=B:
line=1382 tag=M:  English -en (or, rather, the get + -en complex), except that unlike -en which undergoes
line=1383 tag=M:  Affix Hopping, bei and jian each stayed in its head position.) These sentences would then
line=1384 tag=M:  be like the English get passives, properly analyzed as in (56) above (à la Hoshi). The main
line=1385 tag=M:  difference between the Archaic (59)-(60) and the modern (56) is that the Agent appeared
line=1386 tag=M:  as a postverbal PP headed by yu in Archaic, but is completely missing in the modern short
line=1387 tag=M:  passive. Under this hypothesis, the Modern short passive may have developed as
line=1388 tag=M:  follows. First, as is well known, an important change that occurred to the history of
line=1389 tag=M:  Chinese word order is the disappearance of adjunct PPs from postverbal position. It has
line=1390 tag=M:  been argued quite convincingly (see Sun 1996 and references) that the postverbal adjunct
line=1391 tag=M:  PPs did not `move' historically to the preverbal position; they simply fell into disuse in
line=1392 tag=M:  postverbal position. This explains why the modern short form, even though it has a
line=1393 tag=M:  syntax akin to the English get passive, does not include an Agent PP. Secondly, another
line=1394 tag=M:  well known historical development is that the language became highly disyllabic. If the
line=1395 tag=M:  verb disyllabified (as in daibu `arrest'), it continued to head a VP structure under the
line=1396 tag=M:  auxiliary bei, and kept the template available for later development when the VP became
line=1397 tag=M:  more complicated, allowing for preverbal manner adjuncts and `retained objects' as in (59c-
line=1398 tag=M:  d). If the verb did not disyllabify, the auxiliary bei might be cliticized to it (for prosodic
line=1399 tag=M:  reasons, see Feng 1994). This in turn could lead to further development with the result
line=1400 tag=M:  that bei became the first element of a V-V compound or a prefix to the monosyllabic verb,
line=1401 tag=M:  as in bei bu `get arrested', bei fu `get captured' in (57) and (58). When the monosyllabic
line=1402 tag=M:  form of these verbs fell in disuse (and replaced by daibu `arrest' and fulu `capture'), they
line=1403 tag=M:  became bound morphemes, and could not appear in the environments in (60).22
line=1404 tag=M:          An opposite way to relate the Archaic passive forms with Modern short passives
line=1405 tag=M:  is to assume that, at the stage represented by (61) and (62), jian and bei were already
line=1406 tag=M:  prefixes forming a word with the verb. After disyllabification, and the introduction of long
line=1407 tag=M:  passives, the V-V compounds reanalyzed as V'-phrases (a process of what Chao 1968
line=1408 tag=M:  termed `ionization').     These made it possible for the phrasal short passives to be
line=1409 tag=M:  developed.
line=1410 tag=M:  On the other hand, those V-V compounds that never underwent ionization (such as bei bu
line=1411 tag=M:  and bei fu) continued to be compounds, even after the monosyllabic bu and fu fell into
line=1412 tag=M:  disuse, thus exhibiting lexical integrity (i.e., inseparability, etc.) as shown in (60).
line=1413 tag=M:          Whether or not the details of these various analyses are correct, it seems quite
line=1414 tag=M:  certain that the short passive is not simply an Agentless version of a long passive. The
line=1415 tag=M:  short passive in Modern Mandarin is handed down from the Archaic passive construction.
line=1416 tag=B:
line=1417 tag=B:
line=1418 tag=T:               A scholar can be killed, but cannot be insulted.

line=2047 tag=L:         (100) a.     Zhangsan bei pian le.
line=2048 tag=G:                      Zhangsan BEI cheat PERF
line=2049 tag=B:
line=2050 tag=M:  38Some speakers can accept sentences like (94b), with an idiom chunk appearing in the
line=2051 tag=M:  subject position. Washio (1990, p. 258) gives the (i) as being fully grammatical"
line=2052 tag=B:
line=2053 tag=M:         (i)    Nowadays, advantage gets taken of little girls by adult men,
line=2054 tag=B:
line=2055 tag=M:  I assume that for these speakers the verb get has been further weakened (ergativized,
line=2056 tag=M:  grammaticalized) so that in addition to the meaning `to experience', it can also have the
line=2057 tag=M:  meaning approximating `to become, turn out'. In this latter meaning its subject is non-
line=2058 tag=M:  thematic and can host NP-movement. The derivation would be as depicted in (90) for the be -
line=2059 tag=M:  passive: [Advantagei got [t'i [taken t i of John]] , with t' being a trace rather than Pro.

line=2061 tag=M:                                                                                                   43

line=245 tag=B:  6
line=246 tag=M:   Note that extra arguments in English do not occur in postverbal position as frequently as, for instance, in
line=247 tag=M:  German. They are restricted to certain configurations with directional complements that encode bodily
line=248 tag=M:  action. Extra subjects are more widespread in English (see section 3.1).
